DIV1.HEAD: Life of St. George.
Here endeth þe life of seynte Margarete.
And begynneth þe lyfe of the glorious martir seint George.

LG.L: O ye folkes þat here present be
Which of þis story shal haue inspeccion
Of seint George ye may be holde & see
His marterdom and his passion
And how he is protector and patron
Þis holy martir of knyghthode lode sterre
To englisshmen both in pes and werre
In whos honoure sithen gon ful yore
Þe thridde Edwarde of knyghthode most entier
In his tyme by assent of Wyndesore
ffounded þe ordre first of þe gartere
Of worthi knyghtys and ay fro yere to yere
xxiiijti cladde in oo lyveree 13. ffoure and twenty Sh.
Vpon his day kept þe solempnyte
This name George by interupcion 15. by Interpretacyoun Sh.
Is seid of tweyn þe first of holynesse
And þe secunde of knyghthode & renoun
As myn Auctor lyketh to expresse
The devel venquysshyng of maydenhode & prowesse 19. þe feonde venqwysshing Sh.
The worlde þe flessch as kristes owne knyght
Where euer he rode in stele armed bright
Capadoce a myghty stronge contre 22. strong Citee Sh.
As þe storye of him list endite
Ordeyned was in his natiuite
And in his youth he gan him selue delite 25. gaf him self delyte Sh. Variants Sh. = from Shirley's [= Sh.] copy, B = Bodley.
ffro day to day as clerkis of him write
To sue vertu so gynnyng his passage
Vices excludyng al riot and outerage
And cristes feith for to magnifie
Atte gretter age his contre he forsoke 30. be forsoke B; he forsooke Sh.
And þorough his nobelnesse & his chyualrye 31. noblesse Sh.
Trouth to sustene ho so liste to loke
Many a Jorney he vpon him toke
Þe chirch defendyng with swerde of equite
Right of weddewes and virginite
And in þis while an aduenture is byfalle 36. is falle Sh.
Importable þe peple to sustene
Amyddys þe provynce which þat men Lybie calle
In a Cite þat named is Lessene
A grete dragon with skalys siluer shene
Horrible dredeful & monstrous of sight 41. monstruous Sh.
To fore þe Cite lay both day and nyght
The kyng the quene the lordes taken hede
Of þis sodeyn [w]ooful aventure 44. Bodley omits initial w.
And the peple fallyng in grete drede
Consideryng how þey stode vnsure 46. howe þat þey Sh.
As þey þat myght þe myschef not endure
Made by þe assent of þat fel dragon 48. by assaute of that felle dragoun Sh.
By pestelence vpon þer woful toun
But when þe counsel of þe toun toke kepe
How þer peyne was intollerable 51. Howe þat þeyre Sh.
They senten oute euery day two shepe
To þis beste foule and abhominable
To stanch his honger which was vnstancheable
But when þare shepe by processe gan to faile
Thei moste of newe prouyde for more vitaille 56. Shirley has no for.
And when þey founde no refute nor comforte
ffor þe dragon to make purveaunce
When þey token by lot or by sorte 59. þane þey tooke Sh. He writes lines 60, 61 in the reverse order.
Like as it felle on þer mortal chaunce
Man or childe þer vitaille to avaunce
Allas allas it was to grete pitee
To seen þe sorowe þat was in þat Cite
The statute made non excepcion
Of high ne lowe þei stode in so grete dowte
Touching þat monstre and þat foule dragon
Euery maner man as it cam abowte 67. Eche maner man Sh.
To byn deuoured allas þey were sent oute
Til atte last þe lot in his manere 69. in þis maner Sh.
ffil vpon þe kynges doughter dere 70. ffel right vpon Sh.
That she most of necessite 71. most nexst of necessytee Sh.
Ben deuoured þer helpe may no mede 72. Beo so deuowred help may Sh.
But be sent oute of þat Citee
Þis sely mayde quakyng in hir drede
Vpon hir honde a shepe she dide lede
Hir ffader wepte hir moder boþ tweyn
And al þe Citee in terys dide reyne 77. did so reyne Sh.
Atte hir oute goyng hir ffader for the nones
Arrayed hir with al his ful myght
In cloth of golde in gemmys and in stones
Which shone ful shene agayn þe sonne bright
And on hir wey she met an armed knyght
Sent fro þe lorde as in hir defence
Agayn þe dragon to make resistence
Seynt George it was oure ladies owne knyght
That armed sate vpon a riol stede
Which cam to socoure þis mayden in hir right
Of auenture in þis grete nede
Allas qd she whan she toke hede
Bade him fle in his mortal fere
Leste he also with hir deuoured were
And whanne he sawe of hir þe manere
He hadde pite and compassion 93. He hedde B.; and eeke compossyoun Sh.
To seen allas þe cristal stremes clere

On hir chekyns renne and rayl doun 95. chekyns. Note that on p. 7 of his Preface to the Six-Text Chaucer Furnivall speaks of the "scanda∣lous reading" chickens for cheeks in l. 2834 of the Barlow 20 copy of the Canterbury Tales.
Þoghte he wolde be hir champion
ffor lyf for deth from hir not departe 97. nor deeth Sh.
But in hir querel his body to iuparte
Holy seynt George his hors smote on þe side
Whan he þe dragon saw lifte vp his hede
And towarde him he proudely gan to ryde
fful like a knyght withoute fere or drede
Avisily of wit he took gode hede
With his spere sharpe and kene grounde
Thorgh his body he gaf þe fende a wonde
This sely mayde knelyng on hir kne
Vnto hir goddes makyng hir preyere 107. maked hir preyer Sh.
And seint George when he dide hit se
To hir he seide with a benyngne chere
Ris vp anon myn owne doughter dere
Take þi Gyrdel and make þer of a bounde
And lede þis dragon bodyly on þe grounde 112. Sh. apparently has . . . dragon boldely wt þyn honde; but the page is blurred.
Into the Citee like a conqueresse
And þe dragon mekely shal obeye
And to þe Citee anon she gan hir dresse
The owgle monstre dorst it not withseye
And seynt George þe maide gan conveye
Þat when þe kyng had inspeccion 118. hed inspeccion B.
With palms and laurer he goth a procession
Yevyng to him þe laude of his victorye 120. to hem B.: þis victorye Sh.
Which hath there Citee delyvered oute of drede
And seint George to encrese his glorie
Pulled oute a swerd and smote of his hede 123. Pulled oute aswere B.
Þe peple alwey takyng ful gode hede
How god þis martir list to magnyfie
And him to enhance þorgh his chyvalrye
Then he made þe dragon to be drawe
With waynes and cartes fer oute of þe toun
And after þat he taught hem cristes lawe
By his doctryne and predicacon
And from þere erroure by conuersioun
He made hem tourne / þe kynge and þe Cite
And of oon herte baptyzed for to be
The kyng after in þe honoure of marie
And in worship of seint George hir knyght
A ful feire church gan to edifie
Rich of byldyng and wonder feire of sight
Mydde of þe which þer sprong vp anon right 138. Sh. omits vp.
A plesaunt welle with stremes crystallyne
Whos drynke to sike was helpe and medicyne 140. helthe and medecyne Sh.
Seynt George enforme gan þe kynge 141. þanne enfourme gan þe kyng Sh.
Of fowre þynges of grete excellence
ffurst þat he shulde ouer al þyng 143. aboue al oþer thing Sh.
Cristes churche haue in reuerence 144. haue euer in reuerence Sh.
Worship presthode with al his diligence
Haue mynde on pore and first his herte enclyne
Every day to here seruice which is devyne 146. 147. Sh. text is: . . . and his hert enclyne ffrome day to day to hir servyce devyne.
The same tyme þe story tel kan 148. þis same tyme Sh.
Agayn Cristene þer was a tyrant sent
The which was called Dacian 150. was called þoo Dacyan Sh.
Of peynym lawe he was a president
And destroy was holy his entent 151. 152. Sh. writes these lines in reverse order.
The feith of crist and sleen his confessoures
With diuers peynes wroght by his turmentoures
Whan seint George gan hereof take hede 155. Whane þat saint George Sh.
How þis tyrant gan cristes feith manace 156. monace B.
He of purpose lefte his knyghtly wede
And porely cladde met him in þe face
Manly chered fulfilled al with grace
In his presence lowde gan to crye
O god þer is fye on þi ydolatrye 161. Sh. has no þi.
The fals tyrant by grete violence
Commaunded hath anon þat he be take
And to be broght in to his presence
Bad he shulde cristes feith forsake
But he ne liste no delayes make
Answered playnly his lyf by deth to fyne
ffro cristes law no þyng shal him declyne
The tyrant þenne of verray cruelte
Bad þat he shulde þis matere most entere 170. Sh. has the correct reading, þis martir moost entier.
Naked be hanged on a galowe tre
With skorges skorged in ful fel manere 172. With scowrges beet Sh.
And with brondes brennyng bright and clere
His sides brent / were not his peynes stronge
His entrailles open salt cast inne amonge 175. His entraylles opende Sh.
The nyght after criste dede him appere 176. þe nexst night | Cryst to him did peere Sh.
And graciously gan him to comforte
Bad him suffre his peynes with ful gode chere 178. Sh. has no ful.
And in no wyse him seluen dyscomforte
ffor he þe palme of victorie shal resorte 180. shal reporte Sh.
By his sufferaunce and wynnen þe laurere
Of marterdom aboue þe sterres clere
This myght[y] Geaunt Cristes champion 183. B. omits the y.
Dranke bitter venym made by enchauntemente
Cristes croos was his proteccion
Preseruyng him þat he was nat shente
And he þat made it of ful fals entente
Sawe agayn god he hadde no puissaunce 188. he hedde B. Cp. lines 118. 93.
fforsoke his erroure and fil in repentaunce
And axeth mercy in ful hvmble wyse 190. Sh. has no And.
And by came cristen bitwyxt hope and drede
Þe fals Juge fals of al justice 192. voyde of al Iustyce Sh.
Commaunded hath þat he lese his hede
And in his blode as eny rose rede
He was baptised who þat kan deserne
By deth deseruyng þe lyfe þat is eterne
Than Dacian furious and cruele
Gan of new deuysen in his tene
Reysed on lofte a ful large whele
fful of swordes grounde sharpe and kene
And seint George in his entent most clene
Turned þer on in that mortal rage
The whele to brake he felt no damage
Eke in a vessel boylyng ful of lede
The holy martir was plunched doun 205. was eplounged downe Sh.
He enterede inne withoute fere or drede
Þe grace of god was his savacion
And lych a bath of consulacion 208. is omitted by Shirley.
He founde þe metal confortable and clere
Escapyng oute devoyde of al daungere
He was eke broght þe storye doth devyse
In to a temple ful of maumretrye 212. Sh. writes, correctly, mawmetrye.
Of entente to have do sacrifise
But al hir goddis he knyghtly hath defye 214. can defye Sh.
And sodeynly oure feith to magnyfie
A fyre of heuen was by miracle sent
Wherthurgh þe temple was to asshes brent
And with al this we fynden in his lyfe
Thorgh goddes myght & gracious purveaunce
That Alexandria of Dacian þe wyfe
ffor soke ydolas and alle hir fals creaunce
And bycame Cristene with homble attendaunce
Suffred deth baptised in hir blode
ffor love of him þat starfe vpon þe rode
And Dacian þan by a ful mortal lawe
Commaunded hath in open audience
Þat seint George be þorgh þe Citee drawe
And after þat þis was his sentence
He to ben heueded by cruel violence 229. omitted by Sh.
And in his dyeng þis it is byfalle 230. þus it is befalle Sh.
He made his prayer for hem þat to him calle

LG.HEAD: 34. Qualiter Georgius orauit
LG.L: O lorde qd he here myn orison 232. þou here myn orysoun Sh.
And graunt it be vnto þe plesaunce
Þat alle þe folke þat have deuocion 234. Sh. has no þe.
To me / o lorde have hem in remembraunce
And condescende with euery circumstaunce
Of þi mercy o souereyn lorde most dere
ffor my sake to heren þeire preyere
And al þe peple beyng in presence
A vois was herde down fro þe hye heven
How his prayer was graunted in sentence
Of him þat is lorde of þe sterres seven
And Dacian with a sodeyn leven
Was brennt vnwarly by consumpsion
As he repeired home to his mansion

DIV1.TRAILER: Here endeth the lyfe of seynt George
And here begynneth þe prologe of þe xv joyes of our ladye

DIV1.P:
The modern student perceives no occasion for the re∣production of this entire text in the tapestry, were the re∣production of so long a poem possible; and it is difficult to see how a poem so devoid of dramatic emphasis could have furnished the illustrator with points of attachment for his pic∣tures. A similar question, so far as the length of the text is concerned, might be raised regarding the Bycorne and Chiche∣vache: the mode of illustration is there clearer, because Shirley, in his copy of the poem, has transcribed the instructions for the workman. It is possible that the weaver or painter in∣corporated such portions of the narrative as he could repro∣duce, and ignored the rest; and in the case of the poem here printed we might surmise that the verses were not enwrought
in the tapestry (or painted upon the wall), but read as the new mural decoration was uncovered during the "feest of St. George."

However, history gives us no ground for the suggestion. In the destruction which has overtaken nearly all medieval tapestries and frescoes, we are not in a position to affirm that the use of long or of unpictorial texts in decoration was im∣possible. Two inventories of this period, those of Charles VI of France and of Henry V of England, which still exist, enumerate masses of tapestries. In the French list See Guiffrey in Bibliotheque de l'Ecole de Chartes, 48: 59ff.; see 90, 109. we find descriptions of wallhangings à personnages, "ou il y a au dessoubz desdits personnages escriptures et leur noms escripz"; and again a tapestry of "plusieurs autres personnages" where "au dessoubz de elles a grans escriptures"; or "ung tappiz . . . ou y a plusieurs escripteaulx". The appraiser of the English king's possessions Rolls of Parliament 1423, IV: 214-241. gives the opening phrase of the "estorie" upon each piece of tapestry; and we find "Vessi amour sovient", "Cest estorie fait mention", "Comment Bevis de Hampton", "Cest ystorie fait a remembraunce de noble Vierge Plesance", "Par ma foy veisi bon destrer", "Si poez voier en memorie", "Ycy comence pur une message", "Vees Farman premier Roy de France", "Vessi Dames de noble affaire", "Vessi une turnement comenser", "Vessi amans en consolation", "Que voet avoir certain conusans", etc. One in especial should be noticed; it is described as "Une pece d'Arras d'or de St. George, que comense en l'escripture des lettres d'or "Geaus est Agles" ovec les armes de Monsr de Gloucestr". This may have been the St. George tapestry possessed by Thomas Duke of Gloucester See the inventory of Gloucester's goods in Archaeological Journal 54: 275-330.; it is of similar size.

It might again be possible that beside a long romance, e. g. of Charlemagne, there existed one or many brief forms of the story adapted to wall-decoration; as at the close of the list above mentioned there appears "Sy vees le Roy Charle∣mayn." And a briefer form yet of the Emperor's story must have been used if he appeared modeled by the confectioner,
as was the custom to present a tableau, in pastry or sugar, at the close of each course in a medieval banquet. The coro∣nation feast of Henry VI, as recorded by Fabyan, catalogues the meats of the three courses, and then describes the "sotiltee" or subtlety, with its group of figures and its accompanying verse-legend or "reason For example, the third course of that banquet:—"This folowing was the third cours that is for to sey first quinces in compost // Blaunde surre poudrit wt quaterfoylis gilt // veneson rostid // Egrettes // Curlewe // plover // Quaylis · snytes // Grete briddis larkes // Carpe · crabb // leche of thre colours // a cold bake mete like a sheld quaterly rede & white sette with losengis and gilt and flouris of borage // ffritoure crispes // A sotilte of our lady sittyng & hir child in hir lapp and she holding in hir hond a croun and seynt George knelyng on the toon syde & seynt Denyse on the tothir syde presentyng the kynge knelyng to our lady wt this reson folowing
O blessid lady cristis moder dere
And þow seynt George þt callid art hir knyghte
Holy seynt Denyse O martir most entere
The sixt Henry her present in þer sighte
Shedithe of grace on hym your hevenly lighte
His tendir youthe with vertu doith avaunce
Bore by discent and titill of righte
Justly to regn in Englond & in ffraunce."
From the MS St. John's College Oxford LVII, which contains, in the same hand, a copy of Chaucer's Parlement of Foules.." The language of such a stanza, equally with that of the tapestry, required on the part of the versifier a mental attitude nowise differing from that necessary to the composition of a dumb-show or a mumming.
The opening phrases of the "estories" above mentioned, with their "Vessi", should be compared with the opening phrases of the following poem by Lydgate.

DIV1.HEAD: Falls of seven Princes.
Here folowen seven balades made by Daun John Lydegate of þe sodeine fal of certain princes of ffrance and Englande nowe late in oure dayes

LG.HEAD: 1. Kyng Edward of Carnarvan
LG.L: Beholde þis gret prynce Edwarde þe secounde
Which of diuers landes lord was and kyng
But so governed was he / nowe vnderstonde
By suche as caused / foule his vndoying
ffor trewly to telle yowe / wt oute lesing
He was deposed / by al þe rewmes assent
In prisoun murdred / wt a broche in his foundament

LG.HEAD: 2. Kyng Richard þe seconde
LG.L: Se howe Richard of Albyoun þe kyng
Which in his tyme ryche and glorious was
Sacred with Abyt. with corone and wt ring
Yit fel his fortune so / and eke his cas
Þat yvel counseyle / rewled him so elas
ffor mys treting lordes of his monarchye
He feyne was to resigne and in prysone dye

LG.HEAD: 3. King Charlles
LG.L: Lo Charles. of noble ffraunce þe kyng
Taken with seknesse and maladye
Which lefft him never / vnto his eonding
Were it of nature / or by sorcerye /
Vnable he was for to governe or guye
His reaume / which caused suche discencyon
Þat fallen it is to gret destruccyon

LG.HEAD: 4. Þe Duc of Orlyence
LG.L: Se nowe þis lusty Duc of Orlyaunce
Which floured in Parys of chiuallerie
Broþer to Charles þe kyng of ffraunce
His yong hert / thought never to dye
But for he vsed / þe synne of lecherye
His cosin to assent was ful fayene 27. Shirley has a marginal note: i. duc of Burgoigne John.
Þat he in Parys was murdred and foule slayne.

LG.HEAD: 5. Thomas Duc of Gloucestre
LG.L: Of Edward þe thridde / Thomas his sone
Of Gloucestre Duc Constable of England
Which to love trouth it was ever his wone
Yet not withstonding his entent of trouthe
He murdred was at Caleys / þat was routhe
And he to god and man moste acceptable
And to þe comvne profit moste fauorable

LG.HEAD: 6. John Duc of Bourgoyne
LG.L: Lo here þis Eorlle and Duc of Burgoyne boþe
Oon of þe douspiers / and deon of ffraunce
Howe fortune gan his prosparite to looþe
And made him putte his lyff in suche balaunce
þat him navayled kyn nor allyaunce
Þat for his mourder / he mortherd was and slayne
Of whos deth / þermynakes were fayne

LG.HEAD: 7. Þe Duc of Yrland
LG.L: Þis duc of Yrland / of England chaumburleyn
Which in plesaunce so he ledde his lyff
Tyl fortune of his welthe hade disdeyn

Þat causeles he parted was frome his wyff 46. Shirley notes in the margin: i. Launcecrane. According to the chroniclers, e. g. Walsingham (ed. Rolls Series II: 160), the woman for whom Vere in 1387 repudiated his royally descended wife was called "Launcecrona". Walsingham adds "ob quam causam magna surrepsit occasio scandalorum".
Which grounde was of gret debate and stryff
And his destruccyon / if I shal not lye
ffor banned he was / and did in meschef dye

DIV1.P: These few and meagre stanzas contain some of Lydgate's rare allusions to contemporary events. His huge Falls of Princes, derived ultimately from Boccaccio's De Casibus, and ranging all over Biblical and classical history, closes with the "tragedy" of King John of France and his capture by the English at Poitiers in 1356; it contains thus no material for contemporary history and gives no clue as to its date. But the date of this lesser Falls, possibly not remote from that of the greater, is a trifle clearer; for as John of Burgundy was murdered in 1419, and as Charles VI of France died in 1422, the verses must be later than these events. It need not sur∣prise us that the death of Henry V of England does not appear in the list; Lydgate would not consider his death a "fall."

The murders of Orleans and of Burgundy, even of Richard II, are spoken of by Lydgate with remarkable frank∣ness, as is the death of the duke of Ireland, Robert de Vere, Richard's favorite. The emphasis upon Vere's desertion of his wife, recalled by Lydgate more than a generation later as the prime cause of the duke's fall, is interesting. When we recall that that desertion took place in Chaucer's lifetime, we may wonder again if the unfinished Legend of Good Women or the Complaint of Anelida had in it some disguised reflection of the "gret debate and stryff" to which Lydgate alludes. We may wonder also how the Duke of Gloucester, for whom Lydgate executed the mammoth Falls of Princes, the Duke of Gloucester who in 1425 deserted his wife Jacqueline of Hainault even as Vere duke of Ireland had deserted his, would have relished the last stanza. If however these verses were later than 1425, they were perhaps done for some person in private station. The dynasty of Henry the Fourth might not object to plain speaking as to Richard's "mystreting" of their founder; but the tragical ending of one's own royal and noble contemporaries was hardly the sort of death's head which an English lord desired upon the walls of his chamber or in his banqueting hall.
